text: That's true for traditional disk drives where lots of small files are sprinkled around the drive at random. The needed head movement and rotational latency wastes significant amounts of time. With ssds' that problem goes away. The remaining issue is that of finding the true file address which means searching directory sectors. While ssd's still have to do that, the time taken and access speed to the directory sectors is very fast. I organize my files in folders by event type and date (eg "HR230611" for today's horses) which helps minimize the search time when the strategy is given a long list of files to work through for backtest.

The remaining issue is that of finding the true file address which means searching directory sectors. While ssd's still have to do that, the time taken and access speed to the directory sectors is very fast. I organize my files in folders by event type and date (eg "HR230611" for today's horses) which helps minimize the search time when the strategy is given a long list of files to work through for backtest.

text: I think there is a lot of tech like this. I was working  for someone a couple of years ago that asked me to look at NFL tracker data - <http://nfl.com|nfl.com> have a live tracker page for certain games (at least they did). I also worked for a single day at Hawkeye many moons ago but that stuff is all camera based. People have been striving to do this stuff for years. I suppose the problem for many companies is the entry step  into the regulatory bodies around sports. The cynic in my tells me it has to be a great opportunity for sports governing bodies to generate themselves some healthy backhanders.

text:
These are not very mathematical and a bit outdated now but help to see the basis to a few of the more “traditional” handicapping approaches:

• Mordin on Time: A more general view of early approaches to using race times/sectionals
• Anything by Andrew Beyer: similar to above but very USA focused
• Anything by Don Scott: Pretty old and hard to get a hold off but good at getting an early perspective into weight based handicapping/ratings

Anything by Don Scott: Pretty old and hard to get a hold off but good at getting an early perspective into weight based handicapping/ratings
